data.title: Tirana: What to do in the Albanian capital?
data.meta_description: Tirana, the capital of Albania, in the Balkans, is today a trendy destination. We vibrate for its good addresses and its dynamism. Presentation…
data.text:
Visiting Tirana in two days: what to see and do

Skanderbeg Square, the historic heart of Tirana

Any stay in Tirana begins in Skanderbeg Square (Sheshi Skënderbej), a vast esplanade dedicated to the national hero who led the revolt against the Ottomans in the 15th century. The best-known buildings on the square include the National History Museum, the largest in Albania, flanked by a spectacular Socialist Realist mosaic. Nearby, new sites of historical interest, such as the Museum of Secret Surveillance (or the House of Leaves) in the former headquarters of the Sigurimi, the formidable political police, are more particularly interested in the former Communist regime, which fell in 1991.

National History Museum

Sheshi Skënderbej 7

Tirana 1001

+355 42 22 39 77

www.mhk.gov.al

Museum of Secret Surveillance (House of Leaves)

Rruga Dëshmorët e 4 Shkurtit

Tirana 1001

+355 42 22 26 12

muzeugjethi.gov.al

The Pyramid of Tirana, an iconic city monument

Located right in the city centre and opened in 1988, the Piramida was initially set to serve as a mausoleum for the dictator Enver Hoxha (1908-1985) but, however, has never contained his remains. After the fall of Communism, the building was left derelict before being renovated and converted into an information technology centre in 2002.

Bulevardi Dëshmorët e Kombit

Tirana 1001

www.visit-tirana.com

Parku i Madh, Tirana’s green space

Although it is increasingly being taken over by concrete and towers, Parku i Madh (“Grand Park”) is the perfect spot for an impromptu picnic or a welcome break. Featuring a 55-hectare artificial lake, it allows you to cool down at the water’s edge, take a boat trip and even pray in an orthodox chapel. You can also visit a German memorial and a British cemetery from the Second World War there.

Rruga Herman Gmeiner

Tirana 1000

aprtirana.al

Blloku, from the nomenklatura to a hip neighbourhood

Located between Dëshmorët e Kombit Boulevard (dubbed the “Champs-Élysées” ) and Sami Frashëri Street, Blloku was reserved for the Communist elite and forbidden to most Albanians between 1961 and 1991. Today, it is Tirana’s most vibrant district, popular with the local bright young things and tourists. In the centre of the district is found dictator Enver Hoxha’s former residence, Vila 31 (closed to the public). Behind the austere residence, you discover Pjetër Bogdani and Brigada e VIII Streets, the liveliest in the city.

Vila 31

Rruga Thoma Kacorri 2

Tirana 1019

And if you’re staying in Tirana for three days?

Depending on your tastes, you could:

Go to see a contemporary art exhibition in an unusual place, Bunk’Art, a museum set up in a former underground shelter.

Climb up the slopes of Mount Dajti on the Dajti Ekspres, the cable car situated on the exit to the city.

Go shopping in Kruja. This citadel outside of Tirana is home to interesting artisans.

Bunk’Art

Rruga Fadil Deliu

Tirana 1001

+355 67 20 72 905

bunkart.al

Dajti Ekspres

Rruga Mahmut Allushi 56

Tirana 1004

+355 67 40 11 035

dajtiekspres.com

The best places to eat in Tirana

In the city streets

Cheap, typical and unmissable, the famous byrek can be enjoyed at any time in the streets of Tirana. Simply look out for the signs stating tëçastit (“freshly cooked”). This filo pastry stuffed with meat, cheese or spinach is the perfect embodiment of Albanian street food.

Mullixhiu

Regularly ranked as one of the best restaurants in Tirana, this establishment offers a tasting menu that is a delicious overview of Albanian fine food. A warm and friendly address at reasonable prices!

Shëtitorja Lasgush Poradeci

Tirana 1019

+355 69 66 60 444

www.mullixhiu.al

Bujtina e Gjelit

Two kilometres north-east of Skanderbeg Square, this inn is hidden in a magnificent hotel with a swimming pool. Here, almost all the ingredients come from the family farm at the foot of Mount Dajti. Local and tasty!

Rruga Don Bosko 15

Tirana 1000

+355 42 40 58 55

www.facebook.com

A favourite place to stay in Tirana

Hotel Kotoni

Here’s a charming hotel run by a French speaker. Understated and elegant, it is above all ideally located in Blloku, near Skanderbeg Square and the Pyramid of Tirana.
